arrayGenerator

Class CharacterArrayGenerator

  • java.lang.Object
    • arrayGenerator.ScopedArrayGenerator<java.lang.Character>
      • arrayGenerator.CharacterArrayGenerator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ArrayGenerator<java.lang.Character>

    public class CharacterArrayGenerator
extends ScopedArrayGenerator<java.lang.Character>
    Class for generating random strings (arrays of Characters). The strings will be constructed from characters in the alphabet defined by this generator's scope.
    Version:
    October 2019
    Author:
    Hugh Osborne

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      CharacterArrayGenerator()
      If no alphabet is provided, use the default alphabet provided by CharacterScope.
      CharacterArrayGenerator(Scope<java.lang.Character> scope)
      Constructor where the alphabet is provided.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      (package private) java.lang.Character[] createArray(int size)
      A createArray method is required for each non-generic class implementing the generic ScopedArrayGenerator class with a specific type.

      • Methods inherited from class arrayGenerator.ScopedArrayGenerator

        getArray, getScope

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • CharacterArrayGenerator

        public CharacterArrayGenerator(Scope<java.lang.Character> scope)
        Constructor where the alphabet is provided.
        Parameters:
        scope - the scope of the characters permitted for this generator.

      • CharacterArrayGenerator

        public CharacterArrayGenerator()
        If no alphabet is provided, use the default alphabet provided by CharacterScope.

    • Method Detail

      • createArray

        java.lang.Character[] createArray(int size)
        A createArray method is required for each non-generic class implementing the generic ScopedArrayGenerator class with a specific type. This is because we cannot create generic arrays in Java (e.g. T[] array = new T[size]).
        Specified by:
        createArray in class ScopedArrayGenerator<java.lang.Character>
        Parameters:
        size - the size of the array to be created
        Returns:
        an array of Characters of the required size. The values of the Characters will be uninstantiated.
